actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on September 24, 2024.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Burchett moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7764.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Steil moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 7764 — "To establish a commission to study the potential transfer of the Weitzman National Museum of American Jewish History to the Smithsonian Institution, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1735.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1735 — "To coordinate Federal research and development efforts focused on modernizing mathematics in STEM education through mathematical and statistical modeling, including data-driven and computational thinking, problem, project, and performance-based learning and assessment, interdisciplinary exploration, and career connections, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7685.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 7685 — "To strengthen and enhance the competitiveness of American industry through the research and development of advanced technologies to improve the efficiency of cement, concrete, and asphalt production, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7073.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 7073 — "To improve public-private partnerships and increase Federal research, development, and demonstration related to the evolution of next generation pipeline systems, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7630.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 7630 — "To require a plan to improve the cybersecurity and telecommunications of the U.S. Academic Research Fleet, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 8057.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Comer moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 8057 — "To designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 9317 Bolsa Avenue in Westminster, California, as the "Little Saigon Vietnam War Veterans Memorial Post Office"."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to without objection.
Considered by unanimous consent. H. Con. Res. 127 — "Authorizing the use of Emancipation Hall in the Capitol Visitor Center for the unveiling of a statue of Martha Hughes Cannon."
Mr. Steil asked unanimous consent to discharge from committee and consider.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 365
actions-list.actionItem: 20 (Roll no. 442).
Considered as unfinished business. S. 3764 — "To extend and authorize annual appropriations for the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom through fiscal year 2026."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 366
actions-list.actionItem: 21, 1 Present (Roll no. 441).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 8958 — "To reauthorize the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and for other purposes."

actions-list.header: ADJUSTMENT OF THE WHOLE NUMBER OF THE HOUSE
actions-list.actionItem: Under Clause 5(d) of Rule XX, the Chair announced to the House that, in light of the administration of the Oath of Office to the gentlewoman from New Jersey, Mrs. McIver, the whole number of the House is 432.

Representative-Elect LaMonica McIver, Tenth District, State of New Jersey, presented herself in the well of the House for the purpose of taking the Oath of Office which was administered by the Speaker of the House.

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. The Acting Clerk transmitted to the House a copy of a letter received from Ms. Donna Barber, Acting Director of the New Jersey Division of Elections, indicating that, according to the unofficial results for the Special General Election held on September 18, 2024, the Honorable LaMonica McIver was elected Representative to Congress for the Tenth Congressional District of New Jersey.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 257

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. S. 2228 — "To amend the William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021 to clarify the scope of a major Federal action under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 with respect to certain projects relating to the production of semiconductors, and for other purposes."
The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceediings had been postponed.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6219.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6219 — "To require the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to establish a program to identify, evaluate, acquire, and disseminate commercial Earth remote sensing data and imagery in order to satisfy the scientific, operational, and educational requirements of the Administration, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 8958.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 8958 — "To reauthorize the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 2228.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Lucas moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 2228 — "To amend the William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021 to clarify the scope of a major Federal action under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 with respect to certain projects relating to the production of semiconductors, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 670.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bentz moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 670 — "To improve services for trafficking victims by establishing, in Homeland Security Investigations, the Investigators Maintain Purposeful Awareness to Combat Trafficking Trauma Program and the Victim Assistance Program."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 679.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bentz moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 679 — "To amend chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, to require Federal agencies to submit to the Comptroller General of the United States a report on rules that are revoked, suspended, replaced, amended, or otherwise made ineffective."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 3764.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mrs. Radewagen moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 3764 — "To extend and authorize annual appropriations for the United States Commission on International Religious Freedom through fiscal year 2026."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 4698.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 4698 — "To authorize the Joint Task Forces of the Department of Homeland Security, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3208.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 3208 — "To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish a DHS Cybersecurity On-the-Job Training Program, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 9459.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 9459 — "To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to enable secure and trustworthy technology through other transaction contracting authority, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 794.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 794 — "To require a pilot program on the participation of non-asset-based third-party logistics providers in the Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7832.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 7832 — "To require the Secretary of Homeland Security to develop a plan to identify, integrate, and deploy new, innovative, disruptive, or other emerging or advanced technologies to enhance, or address capability gaps in, border security operations, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House resumed debate on H.R. 6231.
The House received a message from the Senate. The Senate passed S. 288 and S. 4698.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6231.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Green (TN) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6231 — "To amend the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to require a prioritized policy issuance review process for the Department of Homeland Security, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6125.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6125 — "To require online dating service providers to provide fraud ban notifications to online dating service members, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 7189.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bilirakis moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 7189 — "To amend the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize a national congenital heart disease research, surveillance, and awareness program, and for other purposes."
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5526.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 5526 — "To amend title XVIII of the Social Security Act to clarify the application of the in-office ancillary services exception to the physician self-referral prohibition for drugs furnished under the Medicare program."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3433.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3433 — "To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act with respect to molecularly targeted pediatric cancer investigations, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 2706.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 2706 — "To prohibit discrimination on the basis of mental or physical disability in cases of organ transplants."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3884.

Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3884 — "To amend title XI of the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize the program providing for sickle cell disease and other heritable blood disorders research, surveillance, prevention, and treatment."

On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 134.

Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 134 — "To require an annual budget estimate for the initiatives of the National Institutes of Health pursuant to reports and recommendations made under the National Alzheimer's Project Act."

On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 133.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 133 — "To extend the National Alzheimer's Project."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 8108.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 8108 — "To amend title XIX of the Social Security Act to add a Medicaid State plan requirement with respect to the determination of residency of certain individuals serving in the Armed Forces."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6829.

Mr. Bucshon moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 6829 — "To amend the Public Health Service Act to authorize and support the creation and dissemination of cardiomyopathy education, awareness, and risk assessment materials and resources to identify more at-risk families, to authorize research and surveillance activities relating to cardiomyopathy, and for other purposes."

The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 5867.

Mr. LaTurner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 5867 — "To designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 109 Live Oaks Boulevard in Casselberry, Florida, as the "Colonel Joseph William Kittinger II Post Office Building"."

The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 6633.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. LaTurner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 6633 — "To designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 9355 113th Street in Seminole, Florida, as the "Army SSG Ryan Christian Knauss Memorial Post Office Building"."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 3851.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. LaTurner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 3851 — "To designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 90 McCamly Street South in Battle Creek, Michigan, as the "Sojourner Truth Post Office"."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 3640.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. LaTurner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 3640 — "To designate the facility of the United States Postal Service located at 155 South Main Street in Mount Clemens, Michigan, as the "Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Jefferson Post Office"."

The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 3639.

The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 2685.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. LaTurner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 2685 — "To make data and internal guidance on excess personal property publicly available, and for other purposes."

The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on S. 1549.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. LaTurner moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. S. 1549 — "To provide the Congressional Budget Office with necessary authorities to expedite the sharing of data from executive branch agencies, and for other purposes."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Self to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by Dr. Ralph B. Lassiter, St. Mark Baptist Church, Omaha, NE.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of September 23.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Debbie Lesko to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
